newsitem.title: JAPAN: Japan's March current account surplus falls.
newsitem.headline: Japan's March current account surplus falls.

text.p: Japan's current account surplus dropped 17 percent in March from a year earlier to 1.03 trillion yen ($8.7 billion), the Finance Ministry said on Wednesday.
Data for the past business year which ended on March 31 showed the surplus slimmed by 24.3 percent to 7.18 trillion yen ($60.8 billion).
Economists have said, however, that the drop in the surplus for the current account would be the last for a while, with sharp rises forecast for April, May and June.
The surplus in the current account -- the broadest measure of trade in goods and services -- has been the focus of trade tension with the United States.
U.S. officials have repeatedly warned that they will not tolerate large increases in the surplus and that Tokyo should not return to relying exports to fuel growth.

But Finance Minister Hiroshi Mitsuzuka has sought to play down the tension, saying that Japan's economic recovery was being led by domestic demand and urging leading nations to take a longer-term perspective on the issue.
